SEARCH
Package pegasus.tensor

Interface Vector<V extends Vector<V>>

Type Parameters:
V - The vector itself (the input parameters and return values of various operations)
All Superinterfaces:
Serializable, Tensor
All Known Implementing Classes:
Quaternion, Vector10, Vector11, Vector12, Vector2, Vector3, Vector4, Vector5, Vector6, Vector7, Vector8, Vector9
public interface Vector<V extends Vector<V>> extends Tensor
A tensor of order 1. Vectors represent a one-dimensional set of scalar components, which are represented by the primitive type double. All vectors are immutable, and a new instance is created after each transformative operation.

A factory method is available for varargs parameters, although it should not be used as a primary means of instantiation. The individual constructors for final types such as Vector2 or Vector3 should be called instead for optimal performance.

Sizes 2-8 are component-based, meaning that the individual components are declared as independent variables. (e.g. x, y, z) Sizes 9 and above are array-based, meaning the components are stored as a primitive array of double values. (double[])

While compound operations can be achieved by method chaining, it is not recommended to do so for complex operations which require several iterations, as unnecessary intermediary vector instances are created in the process. Static methods such as quaternion-vector rotation should be used instead of chaining two quaternion multiplications and two vector-quaternion conversions. (which creates 4 new instances in total)

      Returns:
      The resulting vector
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - When either the provided vector v or the provided merger function is null
